body.p:
"Jerusalem (Holy City) the Glory of all Lands."¬ù ALFRED A. MARCUS,
Diamond Merchant and Importer,
Purchaser of Real Estate, (Landed Property.)
Residence, 127 Dartmouth Street.
No business will be transacted or interviews had on the Jewish Sabbath, from one hour before sunset on
Friday until one hour after sunset on Saturday, or on the Jewish Festivals, and no letters will be opened on
those days.

Revd S. Morais
My dear Sir

I am in receipt of your favor & with
regard to the articles in the record I am quite
satisfied whatever alterations & changes you
make (perhaps it would be as well to leave out
that portion regarding the Queen which Sir Moses
requested me to state. I should also be glad if
you would send an acct to the American Hebrew
the Boston Local papers altho they were anxious to
insert the a/c were crowded out by Political
Matter) I doubt if in any City of the Union
or any place except Ramsgate) the Anniversary
was more beautifully observed in addition to
the services on the Sabbath previous) last
Thursday, of the Even[in]g proceding at both Shules
from Friday Ev[enin]g to Saturday Ev[enin]g. And from Wedne[s]d[a]y
Ev[enin]g to Thursd[a]y Ev[enin]g we kept nine nine (99)

lights burng[?], there was a large attendance, on
Wednesd[a]y Eve[nin]g. we read portions of the psalms
from the commencement of his each letter with his
name, we then made the Blessing over some
Jerusalem wine in the Cup Sir Moses sent
& each person present drank twice once for
Sir Moses & once for themselves[.] Everybody was
Happy & Joyful. I then again addressed
& explained the honor which had been
conferred upon the name of Jew &c.
The press has generally stated that I read
letters from distinguished persons. (I only did
so of a few specially addressed me) one from
Sargeant Dr Hamilton at Washington, Atty Genl Bruston[?]
& Dr. Holmes who is a personal friend and
always writes me so humirously) he
sent the Autocrat at the Breakfast
& his poems to Sir Moses as a birthday
present. (I have recd & forwarded S[?]
but hope to make it ninety nine letters
before the Mail on Tuesday from the
most prominent men in the United
States from President Arthur &
Presidents of Yale College Historical Society

Admirals, Commodores, Senators
Governors, throughout the whole U[nited] States
Judges. Merchants Millionaire &c
I doubt if for purity of sentiment &
composition can be equalled & if
ever they are published by Sir Moses
will make what I sent from Boston
alone, an interesting remembrance of
this great event. (I am sending
Sir Moses conjointly with my family
a most perfect & complete model
of a Fire Engine ever made. I send
him this as the oldest president
of a Life Fire Insurance Comp[an]y
for to be deposited in Guildhall
in in gratitude for the noble great [?]
exertions of the Mayor of London
during the recent oppressions of our
race & Sir Moses Ninety ninth
anniversary[.] Many years ago the
venerable old man presented the
City with a stained window as a
remembrance of his very High

Sheriff before when Victoria was
a maiden.) I am astonished at
the Reformers do they ever forget
how bitter Sir Moses was against
reform many years ago when poor
Dr. Raphael (I mean Dr. Hershell
may his soul rest in peace was alive)
why even in this very city many many
years ago when they first wanted
Reform I said if Sir Moses would
countenance it I should not & they
all laughed me to scorn. Altho I had
done so much for them (Today they make
a great celebration it is the 25th Anversy.
of Dr. Lasker[?] marriage (another great fraud)
I am happy to state I have the honor with
my son to have 3 sittings at Circumci[sio]ns this
week one on Monday (& 2 on Thursday the
same day as Sir Moses) they were both
born on his birthday) Any expence you
may be at I will most gladly pay. Mrs.
Marcus has not yet been able to leave the
house but is improving slowly. God Bless
you, Mrs. Marcus & children unite in
Kind regards & remain Yours truly

The model of an Engine
which you considered so appropriately suted for a
gift to the venerable Sir Moses. I am happy to say
is near completion. I hope within two or three weeks
to have the same ready for shipment. You desire
me to give a description which is a model of Steam
Fire Engine made by George William Clark
formerly apprenticed to Messrs Lambert & Son
London. Residing in Boston 16 years, it took
seven months to make it from a model Salem St.
Steamer No. 8. The boiler is copper works, parts are
steel, the bulk in brass, nickel plate, the height to
the top is 18 inches, length abou 20 inches, with 16th
hole in the nozle pipe. It will throw twenty-seven
feet stream. It has double active pumps, steam
whistle, safety valve and can be attached to any
steam boiler, it has a fluted boiler[.] Although I am
maker of the model I doubt if any other Mechanic

can equal or if there is patience enough in the brain
of any other mechanic to duplicate it, the price you
paid I will give as a bonus to any other fellow
craftsman who will undertake to make so perfect
a model in one year, you think probably that seven
months is a long time to perfect it. The designs
were first made of wood.
